title: William Sio
text:
Aupito Tofae Su'a William Sio (born 1960) is a politician who became a member of the <a href="New%20Zealand%20House%20of%20Representatives">New Zealand House of Representatives</a> on 1 April 2008 for the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Labour%20Party">Labour Party</a> as a <a href="Party-list%20proportional%20representation">list MP</a>. Since the November , he has represented the <a href="M%C4%81ngere%20%28New%20Zealand%20electorate%29">Māngere</a> electorate.
Personal.
Sio is a <a href="Samoans">Samoan</a> who was born in <a href="Samoa">Samoa</a> and came to New Zealand in 1969. He has the "<a href="fa%27amatai">matai</a>" (chieftain title) of Aupito from the Matatufu village of the <a href="Lotofaga">Lotofaga</a> district on the island of <a href="Upolu">Upolu</a>. He belongs to the extended family called Aiga Sa Aupito, which he now heads, as his father, Aupito Pupu Sio, bestowed the title in a 'fa'aui le ula' from father to son. Sio is a <a href="Mormons">Mormon</a> and has served as one of their <a href="Bishop%20%28Latter%20Day%20Saints%29">bishops</a>. He is married with a family of adult and young children.
While growing up in New Zealand during the 1970s, Sio and his family experienced a police <a href="Dawn%20Raids%20%28New%20Zealand%29">dawn raid</a>, which disproportionately targeted members of the <a href="Pacific%20Islander">Pasifika</a> communities. Sio recalled that he was personally traumatised by the raid and that his father, who had recently bought the house, was helpless.
Local politics.
Sio served as a <a href="Manukau%20City">Manukau City</a> Councillor, representing the <a href="%C5%8Ctara">Ōtara</a> <a href="Ward%20%28country%20subdivision%29">ward</a> from 2001. Sir <a href="Barry%20Curtis%20%28mayor%29">Barry Curtis</a>, the <a href="Mayor%20of%20Manukau%20City">Mayor of Manukau City</a>, selected Sio as chair of the planning committee in November 2004. In October 2007, the newly elected Mayor of Manukau City, <a href="Len%20Brown">Len Brown</a>, appointed Sio <a href="deputy%20mayor">deputy mayor</a>, making him the first <a href="Pacific%20Islander">Pacific Islander</a> to hold the position in Manukau City.
National politics.
Labour candidate, 2005–2008.
In the <a href="2005%20New%20Zealand%20general%20election">2005 parliamentary election</a> Sio was ranked 47th on the Labour party list and failed to be elected by two places. However <a href="New%20Zealand%20Labour%20Party">Labour Party</a> list MP <a href="Dianne%20Yates">Dianne Yates</a> left the <a href="New%20Zealand%20House%20of%20Representatives">Parliament</a> on 29 March 2008, and Sio was declared elected in her place (the person above him on the list, <a href="Louisa%20Wall">Louisa Wall</a>, had already been declared elected to replace <a href="Ann%20Hartley">Ann Hartley</a>).
Prior to entering Parliament, Sio was a representative on Labour's national council as Pacific Islands Vice-President.
In opposition, 2008–2017.
In the <a href="2008%20New%20Zealand%20general%20election">2008 general election</a> Sio won the <a href="M%C4%81ngere%20%28New%20Zealand%20electorate%29">Māngere</a> electorate, defeating the incumbent independent (and former Labour) MP <a href="Taito%20Phillip%20Field">Taito Phillip Field</a> by 7,126 votes. In the and s, Sio's majority was approximately 15,000 votes.
In 2013, Sio voted against the <a href="Marriage%20%28Definition%20of%20Marriage%29%20Amendment%20Act%202013">Marriage Amendment Bill</a>, which aimed to permit same sex marriage in New Zealand, with fellow Labour MPs <a href="Rino%20Tirikatene">Rino Tirikatene</a>, <a href="Ross%20Robertson">Ross Robertson</a> and <a href="Damien%20O%27Connor">Damien O'Connor</a>, alongside <a href="Same-sex%20marriage%20in%20New%20Zealand">New Zealand First, Brendan Horan (former New Zealand First MP), and 32 National MPs</a>. The Bill passed, becoming <a href="Marriage%20%28Definition%20of%20Marriage%29%20Amendment%20Act%202013">law</a>.
In government, 2017–present.
Sio was re-elected during the <a href="2017%20New%20Zealand%20general%20election">2017 general election</a> by a margin of 14,597 votes, defeating <a href="New%20Zealand%20National%20Party">National Party</a> candidate <a href="Agnes%20Loheni">Agnes Loheni</a>. Following the formation of <a href="Sixth%20Labour%20Government%20of%20New%20Zealand">Labour-led coalition government</a> with <a href="New%20Zealand%20First">New Zealand First</a> and the <a href="Green%20Party%20of%20Aotearoa%20New%20Zealand">Greens</a>, Sio was appointed as a Minister outside Cabinet by the Labour Party caucus. On 26 October 2017, Sio was appointed <a href="Ministry%20for%20Pacific%20Peoples">Minister for Pacific Peoples</a>, Associate Minister for Courts, and Associate Minister of Justice.
During the <a href="2020%20New%20Zealand%20general%20election">2020 general election</a>, Sio was re-elected in Māngere by a margin of 19,396 votes, defeating National's candidate Loheni.
In early November, Sio became Minister for Courts, while retaining his Pacific Peoples ministerial portfolio. He also retained his associate justice portfolio while picking up the associate <a href="Minister%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20%28New%20Zealand%29">foreign affairs</a>, <a href="Minister%20of%20Education%20%28New%20Zealand%29">education</a> (Pacific Peoples), and <a href="Minister%20of%20Health%20%28New%20Zealand%29">health</a> (Pacific Peoples) portfolios.
After <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20New%20Zealand">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Jacinda%20Ardern">Jacinda Ardern</a> confirmed that the New Zealand Government would apologise for the Dawn Raids of the 1970s and early 1980s, Sio gave an emotional testimony of his family's experiences with a dawn raid, stating that the apology restored <a href="mana">mana</a> for the victims of these raids.
Political views.
Sio's stance against the <a href="Marriage%20%28Definition%20of%20Marriage%29%20Amendment%20Act%202013">Marriage Amendment Act</a>, which allowed same-sex couple to marry, was not popular among his Labour colleagues. He justified his stance based the beliefs of many Pacific Islanders whom he represents.
